metadata.title: To Embrace Open Science More Closely

affiliation.institution: University of Chinese Academy of Sciences

body_text.text: It was on March 19, 2020, only 1 week before the Summit, that the China Association for Science and Technology released a program to fund studies concerning global trends in Open Access and the development approach of Open Access in China. In addition to its interest in Open Access, China encourages the cultivation of world-class academic journals and active participation in the academic publishing industry for the promotion of scholarly communication.

Open Access is a set of principles and a range of practices to ensure free, unrestricted online access to research outputs. It is one aspect of the broader concept of Open Science, which represents a new approach to the scientific process based on cooperative work and new ways of diffusing knowledge by using digital technologies and new collaborative tools.

Open Science, as a research accelerator, 1 will promote the development of science and technology in China. As one of the emerging countries in the world, China is becoming more and more active in the scientific community and collaborations. The total number of full-time equivalent researchers engaged in science and technology in China was estimated to be about 4.19 million in 2018, ranking number one in the world. 2 In 2019, China enrolled 917,000 postgraduate students, with the total number of postgraduate students at school increasing to 2.864 million. 3 All these R&D personnel and students will greatly benefit from Open Access to pub Open Science can also benefit China's transition to an innovation-based economy. As the second largest economy in the world since 2010, China's GDP increased to 99.09 trillion RMB in 2019. 3 According to the 2019 Bloomberg innovation index, China ranked 16 th of the world's most innovative countries, moving from 19 th in 2018. In recent 10 years, China has been pursuing quality of economic growth over speed, underpinning its ongoing transition toward more innovation-driven growth. Traditionally, there has long been a great disconnection between research-driven universities/institutions and application-driven companies. By increasing the research capacity and visibility, facilitating rapid access to novel data and software resources, and creating new opportunities to interact with and contribute to the ongoing communal projects, Open Science may make research collaboration easier for researchers to bond with one another, and especially strengthen the links between universities/institutions and companies. 4 Background Open Science is a movement aiming to remove the barriers to sharing any kind of research outputs, resources, methods or tools, at any stage of the research process. The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is also working for the recommendation on Open Science now, aiming to make access to scientific studies more open and inclusive [5] . Open Science can also create education opportunities, and help developing countries achieve sustainable development. Open Science might be helpful to reduce the widening disparity in terms of digital technology between developed and developing countries through stimulating a wider range of scientific collaboration and innovation by involving more participants and beneficiaries in developing countries.
In summary, global scientific exchanges and economic activities have never been closer.

Open Science will enable us to better meet the global challenges, such as climate change, global health issues, ecological crisis, extreme poverty. Open Science calls for more and more people to contribute and share their intelligence.

Infrastructures and platforms for Open Science have been designed and developed one after another, such as Directory of Open Access Journals, European Open Science Cloud and Open Science Framework. The Open Science Framework, an online system of the Center for OpenScience provides a platform for users to design and create projects, to engage with collaborators, to manage their research using a suite of tools, to prepare their research reports, and to preserve their research outcomes[1].

The principle of "publish or perish" makes scientists keep their ideas secret until published, which may consequently cause secrecy and taciturnity in the scientific community. Through sharing knowledge with others, developing a mutual comprehension of problems, and working collaboratively on research projects, Open Science intends to boost knowledge transfer and provides Open Educational Resources for teaching and learning, including software-based tools and services, and licenses that allow for open development and re-use of content, tools and services [2]. Universities, research institutes, foundations and publishers offer different types of training and consultancy services to students and researchers, to help them develop the skills that are necessary for Open Science practices. In October 2015, Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development published a report on "Making Open Science a Reality", addressing the importance of incentive mechanisms and clear legal frameworks for Open Science at both national and international levels [3]. In April 2018, European Commission published "Recommendation on Access to and Preservation of Scientific Information" and required the member states to set and implement clear policies about Open Science and Open Access [4]. FIGREF5.text: A very encouraging example is shown in the efforts of many research institutions, universities and enterprises around the world who have been working together to fight the COVID-19 pandemic. Some publishers and leading journals have made COVID-19 research outputs free to readers. It is advocated that all the literature, data, clinical trial and other resources related to COVID-19 should be open for free access. So far, there are still some significant barriers and challenges to Open Science, such as intellectual property right, technology and cost. However, it is a belief that Open Science based on sharing and collaboration is not only an inherent need of innovation, but also a responsibility: scientific endeavor, innovation and creativity should benefit the global development for both developed and developing countries. Developing countries are facing various development challenges, such as health inequity, environmental contamination, climate change, food insecurity, education quality. World Health Organization reported in 2005 that more than half of medical institutions have no subscriptions to scientific journals in countries with an annual GNP per capita of less than USD 1 000. This means that Open Access to publications, open research data, open source software, open collaboration, open peer review, open notebooks and open educational resources are especially important for education and research in developing countries.
